Title: NEWS FROM RICHMOND.
Abstract: The flag of truce boat Metamora arrived from Aiken's Landing this morning, bringing down about sixty civilians, sixteen of them ladies, among whom is Gov. BRADFORD'S wife
copyright: Copyright New York Times Company Oct 15, 1862

Title: NEWS FROM THE SOUTHWEST.
Abstract: The Granada Appeal of the 13th inst. makes the result of the Corinth battle even more disastrous to the rebels than our own reports. It is stated that the attack was opposed by all but one of the rebel Generals, meaning, probably, VAN DORN, against whom there is great indignation manifested.
copyright: Copyright New York Times Company Oct 14, 1862

Title: THE LATE VICTORY OF ROSECRANS.

Title: THE GREAT BATTLE AT CORINTH.
Abstract: For several days previous to Friday, the 3d inst., rumors of an attack upon Corinth were prevalent. On the day previous the enemy succeeded in destroy- ing railroad and telegraphic communication. North from Corinth, by burning a bridge and a culvert, pulling up the railroad track and cutting down telegraph poles. They were heard of in every direction. The bluster which precedes the storm was heard on every breeze.
copyright: Copyright New York Times Company Oct 12, 1862

Title: THE VICTORY AT CORINTH.
Abstract: The correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat has the following details of the battle at Corinth: "On the morning of the 3d, our outposts were attacked by the enemy in force, about six miles northeast of Corinth, and before 9 o'clock the engagement became general end fierce, and a sanguinary battle was fought.

Title: GENERAL NEWS.
Abstract: The Union Republican Ratification Meeting, last evening, at Cooper Institute, was most successful. The vast assemblage cordially indorsed the Syracuse nominations of the 24th inst. WM. CURTIS NOYES, Esq., presided, and stirring speeches were made by Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON and Hon. LYMAN TREMAIN, whose patriotic utterances were applauded to the echo.
copyright: Copyright New York Times Company Oct 9, 1862

Title: NEWS OF THE DAY.
Abstract: We have a report by way of Richmond and Fortress Monroe, that a fight has taken place at St. John's River, Fla., but the result is not stated.
copyright: Copyright New York Times Company Oct 9, 1862
Database: ProQuest Historical Newspapers: The New York Times (1851-2009) with Index (1851-1993)

Title: THE VICTORY AT CORINTH.
Abstract: To Major-General Halleck, General-in-Chief: Generals ORD and HURLBERT came upon the enemy yesterday, and General HURLBERT having driven in small bodies of the rebels the day before, after seven hours' hard fighting, drove the enemy five miles back across the Hatchie towards Corinth, capturing two batteries, about three hundred prisoners, and many small arms.
Authors:
HEADQUARTERS OF GENERAL GRANT, JACKSON, Tenn., October 6, 1862 12:20 o'clock.

Title: SOME DETAILS OF THE FIGHTING.
Abstract: As yet we can only state the general results of the fighting at Corinth, Skirmishing commenced Tuesday last, and there has been more or less fighting every day since. The rebel loss is aoout 800 killed and from 1,500 to 1,800 wounded. We have 3,500 prisoners at Corinth and 300 on the Hatchie River and more constantly coming in.
copyright: Copyright New York Times Company Oct 8, 1862

Title: LATER AND IMPORTANT.
Abstract: We can get no distinct account of Friday's battle, at Corinth. On Saturday morning Gen. PRICE attacked Gen. ROSECRANS right while Gens. VAN DORN and LOVELL attacked his left.
